title: Covered Call Case Study (Real Trade Autopsy)

screens.headline: Let's dissect a real 6-month covered call campaign
screens.text: 100 shares of MSFT. $18,000 invested. 6 months of covered calls. What was the result? You'll see every trade, every decision, every mistake - and learn what works in real markets.

screens.headline: The Setup: January 2024
screens.text: Trader bought 100 MSFT shares at $366 on January 15, 2024. Total investment: $36,600. Goal: Generate 2% monthly income via covered calls while holding MSFT long-term. Strategy: Sell 30-45 day calls, 5-7% out-of-the-money, close at 50% profit. Let's see what happened...

screens.question: What was the BIGGEST mistake in this campaign?
options: Selling covered calls at all (limited upside)
Buying back MSFT at $415 after assignment (emotional FOMO)
screens.explanation_correct: YES! Getting assigned at $400 was fine (planned). But buying back at $415 was emotional FOMO. Should have: (1) Waited for pullback, (2) Moved to different stock, or (3) Accepted the $3,950 profit and walked away. Chasing cost $4,900!
screens.explanation_wrong: The real mistake was buying back MSFT at $415 after being assigned at $400. Paid $15/share MORE just to get back in because of FOMO. Emotional trading always loses.

screens.question: The trader made 20% annualized but S&P 500 returned 15%. Is covered calls a good strategy here?
options: No - only 5% alpha isn't worth the work
Yes - generated income in flat/down periods
It depends on the trader's goals
screens.explanation_correct: Smart thinking! For income-focused investors, 20% is excellent. For growth investors, why cap your upside? For emotional traders prone to FOMO (like re-buying at $415), maybe skip it. Strategy is good - but know YOUR goals and psychology!
screens.explanation_wrong: There's no universal 'good' or 'bad' - it depends on goals. Income investor? 20% return is fantastic. Growth investor? Why cap gains? Know yourself and your strategy.

cards.definition: Emotional buying/selling due to fear of missing out
cards.example: Bought back at $415 after selling at $400 (5% premium for impatience)

cards.definition: What you gave up by capping gains with covered calls
cards.example: If held without calls: $7,200 stock gain vs $7,850 with calls

cards.definition: Following rules without emotion (50% rule, strike selection)
cards.example: Feb 1 close at 51% profit was textbook - no emotion

screens.description: Compare alternative strategies on the same MSFT position

scenarios.pros: Generated income even in sideways months

screens.key_insight: Best strategy depends on your prediction. Bullish? Go far OTM or skip calls. Neutral? ATM/slight OTM. Bearish? ATM for max premium.

cards.back: Following the 50% close rule. Generated income during flat periods. Mechanical discipline (except FOMO moment).
Emotional re-entry at $415 after $400 assignment. Cost $4,900. Lesson: Accept assignment or wait for pullback!
Depends on YOU. Income investor? Great. Growth investor in bull market? Maybe not. Match strategy to outlook and goals.
